header.title: How IBM quietly pushed out 20,000 older workers
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Age discrimination can be very hard to prove.. . Read ProPublica's full feature story here:. https://features.propublica.org/ibm/i... . . In a ProPublica feature that collected the stories of over 1,400 former IBM employees, it was estimated that a staggering 20,000 American employees ages 40 and over have been eliminated by the company. How does one of the country's largest tech giants quietly push out this many older workers? Don't we have laws to protect people at the end of their careers? . . Subscribe to the ProPublica newsletter:  http://go.propublica.org/weekly. . Subscribe to our channel! http://goo.gl/0bsAjO. . Vox.com is a news website that helps you cut through the noise and understand what's really driving the events in the headlines. Check out http://www.vox.com . . 0:50 60 per cent of those affected by IBM's job cuts were 40 years or older.

IBMs employees mostly went to college first, so they start working with something like 23 years. Then they work till they are at least 60.

I'm 58 and I have almost always had multiple job offers, including many former employers. Had a layoff only once for two weeks when I was young due to business turn-down. The trick is to stay as current and knowledgeable in your field as possible - Look for trends in your field that may give you clues as to where it is headed. But do not limit yourself to one field either. Be willing to work sometimes unpleasant tasks without complaint - be flexible with work hours, assignments and tasks. Get as much training as you possibly can, especially outside your comfort zone. Your have to be willing to change jobs and employers often. Don't get pigeonholed into repetitive tasks. I change companies on average about every 5 years on my own initiative in order to maximize wages, because I get the highest wage increases when I move to a new employer. Then try to save and invest some percent of your extra income. Don't waste your money buying ready made meals, make your own coffee and sandwiches at home. Don't saddle yourself with crazy amounts of debt if possible. Find your happiness outside work, work is to make money period ... Think of your self as a product that the employer needs, and make sure you are the best product he can buy by continuously self-improving. Be ready at all times for layoff! Don't let your employer define who you are and have no fear of a layoff. I have purchased equipment that would help me start my own business if I had to, but I have not needed to yet so it will be re-sold upon my "retirement." Do not be loyal to the company besides giving an honest days work, especially in an environment where it won't be recognized and rewarded. You must look out for yourself and your family first. (edit) And don't let yourself get too stressed out...it can lead to bad health and death and then you won't be any good to anyone...if your job stress affects your health you need to bail...

I worked for IBM as a contractor from 2007 through 2014. During that period there were at least five layoffs that I was aware of. Nearly all of the non-contract employees affected were long-term employees with 20 or more years at IBM. To be fair, they were given fairly generous severance packages and most were pension eligible. However, most were not ready to retire and were essentially forced into it. Bottom line is IBM management was eliminating older pension-eligible workers in favor of younger workers with limited benefits and no pension. It's age discrimination for profit, plain and simple. I actually felt lucky that I was contract, I survived those layoffs mainly because I was a fixed, hourly-rate employee with no benefits. By all rights I should have been let go in favor of a direct employee, but it was all about the $$, employees be damned. When they talk about how their employees are their most valued resource, etc., they are flat-out lying. Towards the end was forced to accept a rate cut, then management decided they would arbitrarily furlough the contractors for weeks at a time (gotta make those year-end numbers look good). I left in the summer of 2014 and haven't looked back, better job now, more money and full benefits. IBM is not a company I would ever work for again. If you're just graduating with a STEM degree and thinking about applying there, don't walk but RUN elsewhere.

You had to be very good, or you needed to learn new skills to stay in the game. Older employees generally have higher salaries and compensation due to seniority of job titles, and are more likely to be in management positions. When conducting layoffs to restructure or cut costs, high paying and management positions are often the first eliminated. It's not that IBM targeted older workers, it's just that IBM targeted higher paying positions and management positions in its elimination of positions, which happened to impact older workers more. As for the "their performance review discriminatinated against older workers": No, it didn't. Generally, you would expect more of a senior employee than a younger one, as they've had more time to learn, adapt to the environment of the company, and they're getting paid more. So obviously you're not going to hold a fresh grad making $45,000 a year to the same standards as a senior developer making $120,000 a year. With a fresh grad that needs a lot of assistance, I'd be willing to work with them to get their performance up to invest in that employee. If someone that's been at the company 25 years is needed constant supervision and struggling to perform well, and making 6 figures, I'd be skeptical of that employee's value to the company. Lastly, they offered far better retirement and severence packages than is required by law. They could've fired their employees and provide d nothing, but instead they provided many months of severance pay and early retirement packages, which were quite nice. If I was working at IBM and was offered an early retirement package, I probably would've taken it.

As somebody who worked for IBM for a few years, what IBM is doing maybe bad for their workers, but you have to understand that this is necessary, and its not just about outsourcing and H1bs, it's much more nuanced than that.
A. It's not just the aging workforce that is the problem, it is aging technology. IBM has been losing money for years, and they needed to evolve. This is why everything you here out of Ginni's is "blockchain" or "cloud". IBM needs to shift the expertise of their employees into these new technologies, meaning somebody who's been doing COBOL for 30 years suddenly needs to do distributed systems or some other flavour of the month technology. If he is basically starting from scratch, it's in IBM's best interest to hire a younger worker because 1. younger workers have a tendency to be familiar with new technology, 2. Even if they are both starting from scratch with this new technology, the new worker is cheaper, and his training him is more cost effective because he can work for 20 years more than the older worker, who you will train for maybe a year but will retire in 5. That isn't even considering the trend for older workers to be harder to train and be dead set on what they know and resist an effort to deviate on that.
B. A lot of US tech workers have these horror stories with regards to their experiences with outsourcing, but this seems to be the exception and not the rule. Companies are getting more things done and saving more money by outsourcing their all aspects of their systems. As somebody who has first hand experience on this process, I've seen what an army of freshly graduated Filipino IT practitioners can do, and with some guidance, they can handle themselves well and will even sometimes exceed your expectations. And the days of seeing outsourcing as simply call center work is done, these outsourced professionals are designers, testers, architects, support specialists, and every other IT discipline you can think of, all working in a foreign country, available for a fraction of what you will pay for a US team. How are companies supposed to justify retaining experienced but expensive employees when you can hire a whole unit of 50 guys for the equivalent of one of their salaries? 
C. How employees approach work has also evolved. People don't stay at companies for long, even 5 years is considered a long time today. Employees have to keep evolving, learning new skills, looking for new opportunities elsewhere. Gone are the days of retiring at the same company where you started your career. So in order to attract talent, employers have also shifted what they offer, opting for more money upfront, but a less stable job environment. Again, speaking from experience, it may be a bad time to be an employee, but it's a great time to be an independent contractor or freelance agent.
IBM is simply trying to adapt to the times. Older employees are having a bad break, and what's happening to them isn't fair, but in IBM's mind, if it doesn't do this, its very existence will be in danger.
If a person is a valuable asset to a company, they will not be laid off. No matter whether they are young or old. That's it.

I worked at IBM as a developer on an internship from 2014-2015. If you look at October of 2014, you'll see a sharp spike downward in their stocks, that they've yet to recover from. I remember being there when that happened. Things changed dramatically after that. Much like the story and video say, a lot of very experienced developers never came back after Christmas vacation. Sweeping organizational changes were attempted to be put in place, trying to change to an "agile and fast approach," all of which felt incredibly rushed, desperate, and really didn't scale to the size of the organization they were trying to apply it to. They made a short attempt at trying to adopt a more startup-like young culture with office parties, lunches between upper management and us university interns, and event outings but it just resulted in more alienation of the older demographics. At the end of my internship, our team that had some ~80 student interns was replaced with 15. It felt like they had just given up. A few interns I worked with went back to IBM afterwards, but not many. It was bad. I've never seen a company so desperate to find it's place in a world that had seemingly left it behind, and then just give up.

I don't want to sound inconsiderate, but this feels like it's IBM doing their part to combat corporate bloat.  As a company gets older you get jobs that used to be essential, but that get replaced, automated, or incorporated into other areas.  So you end up with older employees where you ask yourself 'What exactly is it that they do...?'  But no one dares to bring it up, because they have seniority.  Even if they don't actually do anything, they've been at the company for decades!

This is how you get massive corporations that get out-competed by younger start-ups with a tenth of their workforce.  It's because the big guys are carrying a bunch of dead weight.  Just look at Microsoft Office vs freemium competitors like Libre Office.  It's not normal that Microsoft's team is falling that far behind in terms of basic efficiency in a text editor.

I mean, granted, if there is actual discrimination (where an older employee of equal or greater skill to the younger ones gets fired instead of the younger ones) that is wrong.  But I get the feeling that, often with these sort of situations, the employer is getting rid of them because they're no longer useful.  And that's sad, but the company doesn't make a profit by being a charity.

Correlation does not imply causation. In a rapidly-changing field like technology, it's only natural that older people with an older set of skill will be having an outdated set of experiences, skills and approaches that will be less useful to a company every passing day. And with age comes the resistance and inability to adapt to new technology. Being laid off probably meant that their outdated skill sets and experiences were not being useful to the company, and it's not necessarily true that they were laid off simply because they were "old". I am not speaking against protection from being laid off after decades of service to a company. But if you want to argue against this specific case of laying off, calling it "age discrimination" will probably be barking at the wrong tree and may not be helpful at all.

Cheap labour did exist before, BUT the key factor is cheap, high-speed, high-throughput global transportation of goods which makes it so easy to relocate as a company. Thus the workers of one country don't just directly compete against each other, but now workers from other countries too. Supply goes up, wages fall. With regards to IBM's old tech, nobody can crack those remotely sure, but they're so out-dated hardware and software-wise, they're practically useless. commentThread.commentText:
IMHO, older workers delaying their retirement is part of why the unemployment rate is so high. The job market is kind of like a popular restaurant with a line of people waiting to be seated. Older workers are the people currently occupying some of the tables. They've finished their dinners and paid the check. But instead of getting up and leaving, they're continuing to sit at the table and chat. Technically they have every right to do that, but the people in line waiting for a table suffer for it. The same applies in job availability and mobility in several industries. 

I once worked at a company where the only chance to be hired or promoted was if someone above you retires or dies. I have a lotta friends who have been rotting away in middle management for decades waiting for their 70+ superior to retire so they can finally get promoted. Meanwhile, the superior is taking long lunches, longer vacations or may be coming to work only a few days a week. Yet and still they're allowed to maintain their full salary and job title. The consequences are paid by the people under them who are expected to take on some of the supervisors' uncompleted work. They're basically given the majority of the work associated with being promoted, without the title or salary increase. So it's no wonder that even employed young people are struggling.

Older people are usually working on the older tech, because they were the ones who designed them. Its full time to support the job (many times way over full time) and the company demands it because of contracts. If the older worker wants to learn new tech, it has to be done on their limited free time. And being older, what free time you get means more time with family demands, taking care of older parents, etc.. Older workers had raises and more likely are in old fashion stock/bonus plans, which is rarely given to new hires. So yes, older workers are expensive. As the old tech is phased out, the new hires were working on next gen products. Only a few older workers are kept, the rest are given the boot. If the employee was nice, its usually a layoff package. If they were troublesome or a complainer, its usually a termination based on a magic HR rule invented for that day. Its less expensive to hire new and place into the new products than transfer older employees. Older employees also have many drawbacks to get a new job. Starting salary is higher, hiring manager knows that older worker will need more doctor visits, leave early for kid stuff, less likely to work a 90hr/week. etc.... So even if the older worker will accept a paycut to get back into the workforce, hiring managers do not want someone older than them (fear of someone knowing more than them), and same reasons above. My advice, be a contractor and job hop every chance you get. Make sure you are always working on the latest trend. Never EVER stay in one place for more than 2 years. The raises you will get on job hopping are much better than the farce of "long term bonus plans" on staying in a job. Source: 18 years as a gd dam tec h monkey, getting 1% raises, making millions for a company and my only reward are many kudo emails from ceo/exec staff, working on holidays, many odd titles as systems engineer/senior programmer/QA analyst/sales engineer/ staff engineer. Go into medicine. They will pay overtime. Eventually everyone gets sick so there is always demand. Until they make a medical robot, you're job will never be outsourced/laidoff. And experience is usually valued there. Most places pay for training on new ways of medicine. Me? 45, last job moved to china. 2 years looking for work. Looking to become a copy machine repair man. That is what EE with honors at a major university got me.

I tend to be skeptical of any anecdote that doesn't closely match what I have seen myself.  Maybe that fellow's father DID succeed at IBM and is still there.  Maybe it's also due to hard work and staying current.

My experience has been that young STEM workers have a very difficult time taking a long-term project from beginning to end.  It's not their fault, because they've never done it in real life (imperfect specs, imperfect data, office politics, unrealistic expectations, etc.).   The last I read, roughly FIFTY PERCENT of software projects fail completely.  I was lucky - mine all worked, but I also took a bit more time planning for the unexpected.  We rarely hear about projects that fail, but experienced workers can spot doomed projects pretty quickly, but what company wants a bunch of graying forty-somethings around?  Ewwww!

Bottom line: beware of confirmation bias, and don't assume all business decisions are rational.

Contracts of any kind require equal compensation and informed consent to be legally binding, this is why I can't slip in a 'I get to burn your house down' in a contract you signed to borrow my lawn mower. 1.) Borrowing my lawnmower isn't worth as much as your house and 2.) You might not have known/understood what it meant when I slipped that clause in a 30 page paper to borrow my lawnmower.

In IBM's victim's case, the question would be, "Is violating your rights as an older citizen worth the pension they give in exchange, and did you understand that's what was going in when you signed the contract." The answer to both of these questions is no, but you'd have to prove in a court of law that 1.) IBM's layoffs unfairly targeted older workers, 2.) That the victims didn't understand the rights they had when they were signing, and 3.) That the pensions aren't enough compensation for having your rights violated. Unfortunately all that requires much more than what a YouTube comment can provide.
